name: Miko Pawlikowski
title: Keynote: 7 Deadly Traps of SRE
abstract:
Site Reliability Engineering was never meant to be about firefighting, yet too many teams find themselves stuck in an endless cycle of pages, postmortems, and quick fixes. Why? Because SRE is full of hidden traps — patterns that look like best practices on the surface but slowly erode reliability, burn out engineers, and stall progress.

In this talk, we’ll expose the 7 Deadly Traps of SRE, from the obsession with chasing “five nines,” to the cult of on-call heroism, to the false comfort of tooling and checklists. For each trap, we’ll unpack why it’s so seductive, how it quietly sabotages your team, and what to do instead.

You’ll walk away with a clearer lens on the pitfalls holding SRE organizations back, and a practical playbook to help your team escape firefighting mode and reclaim the true purpose of SRE: building systems - and cultures - that are resilient, scalable, and human-friendly.
bio: Miko Pawlikowski is an SRE Author and a platform engineer at Quadrature. He has led large-scale infrastructure and SRE initiatives at Citadel and Bloomberg, with deep expertise in Kubernetes, cloud computing, and chaos engineering. Passionate about building resilient systems and communities, he brings together engineers worldwide through conferences and media projects.

name: Nitish Mane
title: AI-Driven Platform Engineering with MCP
abstract: The session is practical and experience-driven, covering real-world use cases across infrastructure, Kubernetes, observability, and incident response. I believe it would resonate well with engineers building and operating modern platforms.
bio: Nitish Mane is a senior software engineer specializing in large-scale cloud infrastructure, platform automation, and reliability engineering. He has led global cloud expansions, built AI-driven systems, and delivered significant cost and operational efficiencies across AWS and Oracle Cloud in high-growth, regulated environments.

name: Priya Ranjan Sahoo
title: SRE in a Multicloud World: Engineering Reliability Beyond a Single Cloud
abstract: Multicloud promises resilience but often introduces fragmented observability, unclear ownership, and harder incident response. This talk shares real world lessons applying SRE principles, SLIs, SLOs, error budgets, and on-call models across multiple cloud providers. We explore what breaks when a single-cloud assumption fails and the patterns that ensure reliability.
bio: I am a Principal Engineer with Oracle,  specializing in MultiCloud Engineering for Oracle Databases. I have led the design and operation of Oracle Databases spanning AWS, Azure, Google Cloud, Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI), and private cloud environments, with a strong focus on reliability, observability, marketplace integration and operational excellence.

name: Michael Jiang
title: Taming Giants: Managing 70B+ Param Models in Air-Gapped Clouds
abstract:
As generative AI moves from the cloud to the edge, we are colliding with a hard reality: physics. Deploying 500GB-plus models into disconnected, resource-constrained environments—such as air-gapped critical infrastructure—exposes fundamental limits in today’s containerization and delivery patterns. Docker layers time out, container registries collapse under load, and application startup times stretch beyond 45 minutes, rendering traditional approaches impractical.

In this talk, I’ll walk through a battle-tested architecture designed to break this “physics versus physics” deadlock. The approach reframes how we package and deliver large language models at the edge by decoupling lightweight inference engines from massive model weights using OCI Artifacts, enabling far more flexible deployment strategies. I’ll also introduce a sideloading ingress pattern that bypasses container registries entirely, injecting model data directly from object storage to eliminate registry bottlenecks during large, concurrent transfers. Finally, I’ll share a practical quantization decision matrix that makes it possible to run 70B-parameter models within the constraints of a single A100 GPU.

This is not a theoretical exploration. The architecture was validated in production during Exercise Mobility Guardian 2025, where it powered GenAI workloads on a GDC appliance in fully disconnected, zero-internet environments. Attendees will leave with concrete patterns and lessons learned for deploying large-scale generative models where bandwidth, connectivity, and startup time are non-negotiable constraints.
bio: I specialize in AI infrastructure and edge reliability at Google based on SF Bay Area, currently focusing on solving the "Sovereignty Paradox" for secure environments. My work sits at the intersection of SRE, platform engineering, and critical infrastructure resilience.

name: Nishkarsh Raj
title: Q the Savings: How We Built a $2M/Year FinOps Platform in 2 Weeks
abstract: We built a AI FinOps platform in 2 weeks with Kiro and AWS Bedrock that found $2M in annual AWS waste— without buying expensive tools. 13 automated scanners, gamified leaderboards, AI recommendations, and one-click cleanup. I'll show you exactly how we did it and how you can too.
bio: Nishkarsh is a DevSecOps expert and an International GitHub Star. Nishkarsh is an ardent supporter of open-source, GitHub, DevEx, and DevOps. Nishkarsh serves as StatusNeo Inc.'s Principal Evangelist & Consultant. Over the years, he has been actively GitHubbing and contributing to open-source. By giving talks at conferences, organizing meetups, and encouraging people to take on the #100DaysofCode challenge, he has encouraged many brilliant minds to embark on their journeys in open-source projects and preach the significance of collaboration to aspiring developers.

name: Sureshkumar Karuppuchamy
title: AI at the Helm: Using Generative Models to Accelerate Incident Response and Platform Health
abstract: AI is no longer research-only — it’s practical for accelerating SRE workflows. This talk presents production patterns for applying LLMs and ML to alert triage, root-cause suggestion, post-incident analysis, and runbook automation while maintaining safety and explainability. We cover data requirements, model-inference placement, human-in-the-loop design, and metric frameworks to measure risk vs. benefit. The session includes examples of improved MTTD/MTTR, common failure modes, and governance strategies to keep AI from amplifying operational risk.
bio:
Sureshkumar Karuppuchamy is a technology leader with more than two decades of experience designing and modernizing large-scale, AI-enabled infrastructure for some of the world’s most complex platforms. In his current role as a senior engineering leader at eBay, he has led critical modernization efforts across core systems—revamping legacy platforms, transitioning to cloud-native data solutions, and reimagining API architectures to improve agility, reliability, and scalability.
His work includes the development of advanced compliance systems that support real-time moderation and auditing in alignment with global regulations like the EU Digital Services Act. He’s also helped shape seller experience through intuitive listing flows and AI-powered tools that streamline product onboarding, such as transforming product images into fully generated listings.
Sureshkumar’s contributions have been featured in publications including The Guardian, Deloitte WSJ Insights, and marketscreener.com. He began his career at Oracle, building enterprise solutions for global supply chains, and is a graduate of Anna University’s College of Engineering, Guindy.
Passionate about knowledge-sharing, he mentors technologists, contributes to peer-reviewed research, and regularly speaks at international conferences on system architecture, AI, data platforms, and compliance tech.

name: Akshay Pratinav & Sahil Sabharwal
title: From Compute to Datastores: Predictable Region Failover for Microservice Stacks
abstract: Outages happen. At Intuit, a Kubernetes-native platform makes region failover boring: services declaratively onboard; we pre-scale from live traffic, promote standby DBs, and shift routes via Route53/Istio—slashing recovery time and standardizing resilience for hundreds of microservices.
bio:
What's up folks, I'm **[Akshay Pratinav](https://www.linkedin.com/in/akshaypratinav/)**, I’m a Staff Software Engineer with deep expertise in cloud‑native distributed computing and resilience engineering. My career spans critical roles building internal developer productivity tools, where I’ve consistently delivered impactful, high‑performance solutions. In my current role at Intuit, I am leading the development of an internal Disaster Recovery platform that’s a non‑negotiable imperative for maintaining business continuity and customer trust. I also played a key role in the ITSM initiative, automating and streamlining incident management and significantly reducing Mean Time to Detect (MTTD) and Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR) for major incidents. Additionally, I was instrumental in the design and development of the Policy Enforcement platform, providing a sophisticated, unified, and consistent experience for authoring, deploying, and enforcing policies across diverse cloud and Kubernetes infrastructure—embedding security, compliance, and operational efficiency.

Hi, I'm **[Sahil Sabharwal](https://www.linkedin.com/in/sahil-sabharwal-a660815b/)**, Senior Engineering Manager at Intuit, where I lead core platform team focused on disaster recovery and resiliency for Intuit’s large-scale Kubernetes applications—including TurboTax and QuickBooks—running on AWS.
Prior to Intuit, I worked at Nutanix, where I helped build the in-house private container registry (NCR) and the Nutanix Kubernetes Platform (NKP). I also held engineering roles at Juniper Networks and IBM Cloud, where I contributed to the open-source cloud infrastructure project OpenStack. I hold a Master’s in Computer Engineering from North Carolina State University, where I completed my thesis under Dr. Eric Rotenberg. Most recently, I had the opportunity to present my work and product innovations at AWS re:Invent 2025.

name: Anjana Shree Sundar
title: Engineering Predictive, AI-Driven Reliability: Transforming Verizon Global Infrastructure Operations with SRE Automation and Digital Twin Intelligence
abstract: Discover how Verizon is engineering predictive, AI-driven reliability at scale using SRE, automation, and an Intelligent Digital Twin. Learn the blueprint for transforming operations from reactive to proactive with real-time insight, automation, and GenAI-powered decisioning.
bio:
Anjana Shree Sundar is a seasoned consultant and solutions architect specializing in site reliability engineering, cloud modernization, and large-scale banking platforms. With more than sixteen years of experience, she designs fault tolerant, highly available systems and leads transformations from reactive operations to proactive SRE models. Her expertise spans architecture governance, target state definition, and hands-on delivery across enterprise COTS implementations and custom integration patterns. She is known for aligning technology with business outcomes, accelerating incident recovery, and embedding automation to reduce toil and improve operational efficiency.

Anjana Shree Sundar is an exceptional SRE specialist who led the comprehensive strategic transformation of Verizon Global Infrastructure (VGI) operations by implementing advanced Site Reliability Engineering (SRE) practices, robust automation frameworks, and AI/GenAI-driven operational intelligence. This initiative centered on developing a cutting-edge Discovery and CMDB platform to create an Intelligent Digital Twin of all infrastructure and network assets, providing real-time visibility and configuration management. By deploying AIOps capabilities for predictive analytics, anomaly detection, and event correlation, the project targeted significant reductions in operational toil and Mean Time to Repair (MTTR), aiming to achieve continuous reliability, enhanced system resilience, and a technology-driven, intelligent operational framework across Verizon's global infrastructure.

At Citizens Bank, Anjana serves as Senior Architect for SRE Transformation with Infosys, mentoring teams and establishing SLOs, SLIs, SLAs, and KPIs to measure reliability, performance, uptime, and responsiveness. She builds observability programs with Datadog and Splunk, orchestrates incident response and learning-focused post-mortems, and advances chaos engineering and IT resilience testing. Previously, she led AWS modernization and product migration for the Transmissions portfolio covering IBM Sterling Integrator, Globalscape, Connect:Direct, and Seeburger where she planned and executed migrations, implemented cost and performance optimization, and stood up end-to-end monitoring and logging. Earlier, as Technology Architect for consumer and commercial portfolios, she created T-shirt sizing estimation models for production support, codified operational-resiliency standards with architecture boards, and led Fit-for-Use and Fit-for-Purpose assessments to guide investment. She partners closely with engineering, product, and operations leaders to align roadmaps with reliability goals.

Anjana’s skill set includes multi-cloud (AWS and Azure), API-first architecture, DevOps and CI/CD, and observability. She works with Terraform, Jenkins, Bitbucket, GitHub, Ansible, Venafi, Gremlin, and AWS services including EC2, EBS, EFS, ALB, NLB, RDS, Route 53, KMS, Lambda, and S3. She implements integration with Seeburger, IBM Sterling B2B Integrator, SEAS, Secure Proxy, and Connect:Direct; and develops in JavaScript, Python, SQL, PowerShell, C, and C#. Database experience spans SQL Server, Oracle, MySQL, Postgres, DynamoDB, and Cosmos DB, with analytics in Power BI and Tableau. She is a collaborative leader who mentors teams and drives measurable gains in reliability, cost, and efficiency.

Anjana holds the AWS Certified Solutions Architect – Professional (valid through November 22, 2027), TOGAF 10 Enterprise Architecture (OGEA-103), and ITIL Foundation. She earned a Bachelor of Engineering and an MBA from Anna University. Based in Frisco, Texas.

name: Charit Upadhyay
title: AI-Augmented Incident Response: From Alert Fatigue to Faster Root Cause at Scale
abstract:
As SRE teams grow, incident response often slows under the weight of alert noise, weak signals, and manual triage. This talk explores a pragmatic approach to improving incident detection, triage, and root cause analysis by combining strong SRE fundamentals with targeted AI assistance.

Drawing from real production workflows, the session covers how better signal design and contextual enrichment can reduce alert fatigue, how AI and LLMs can accelerate triage, log analysis, and hypothesis generation, and where automation should stop to preserve operational trust. Attendees will hear concrete lessons learned from real incidents and platform-scale reliability challenges, with a focus on improving MTTR without over-engineering.

This talk is aimed at practicing SREs and platform engineers looking for practical, trustworthy ways to augment their existing reliability workflows.
bio: Charit Upadhyay is a Senior Site Reliability Engineer at Adobe, working on platform reliability for large-scale compute and query services. He previously worked as an SRE at Oracle, focusing on Kubernetes, Terraform, CI CD pipelines, and large distributed infrastructure. Charit is an IEEE Senior Member, a frequent conference speaker, and a regular reviewer of research papers in the reliability and systems space.
